- My dad always used to talk
about evolving as a person

and as a human and embracing
change and pursuing growth.
People ask, how did OCEARCH start or begin
and I think really it's been an evolution.

We started taking
scientists out on the water
and we really began to just explore
the rate of data collection.

Around 2005, they all
started talking about
the shark problem.
- White sharks are a worldwide species,
they live in many places around the world
and they've been very well studied.
But interestingly enough,
here in the Western north Atlantic,
they've been very poorly understood.

- And in other parts of the
world, in Africa and Australia,

and on the west coast
of the United States,

they've been studying their
white sharks for decades.
- And often those scientists are working
kind of in a vacuum,

they're not working with
big teams of people.
We're taking a different approach.

- [Chris] We began to bring
big collaborative teams around

and we were able to kinda
force that collaboration
because it was the only ship in the world

where they could have access
to these large animals
in a safe way.

- We're also obviously concerned
with individual animals

when they're in our
care for the 14 minutes
that we're working on them.

It's also important for
OCEARCH in particular
because of our unique methodology

of picking these animals
up out of the water.
We obviously really wanna understand

what's happening with them,
that they're well ventilated
and that they handle the process well.
- It's about being super efficient,
taking the maximum leap forward

with the minimum amount
of animals touched.
- [Robert] So we're bringing scientists in
from more than 30 different organizations

who are doing unique
projects that run the gamut

from molecules all the way up
to their movement patterns.

- It's basic blood
work, like blood counts,

it's chemistry panels that help
us understand organ health.
We look at different inflammatory markers
to understand whether or not

they have potentially
inflammation or disease.

- And in just seven years,
we've gone so far beyond

where anyone else in the world
has gone in understanding
the life of a white shark population.

- [Robert] We have basically
accelerated knowledge

of the white shark from
one of the least understood
to probably the most understood.

- The life of the white
shark off the east coast

of the United States
is no longer a mystery.
- So with success comes more questions,
it also brings new challenges.

- Because we have so
many different studies,

everybody is collecting
different data sets.
And the amazing thing about health data

is that it feeds into
so many other studies.

So a lot of the data that we
need to help us understand

these animals better come from
lots of different sources.

So we spend a lot of time
trying to make that data

go into a format where it
all can talk to each other.

- This is where we turn to
AWS for help because AWS

with its computing power can
give us answers within minutes.

ASDI is a perfect partner
for our organization

because we're able to
look at the conditions

surrounding these animals
in many different formats
and we merge that with our tracking data.

And all of a sudden, we've taken
our science to a new level.

This is something we could not
do before that now we can do
and are doing with ASDI.

- ASDI or the Amazon
Sustainability Data Initiative

is a Tech for Good Program
and what we're trying to do
is try to create more innovation
in the space of sustainability.
- ASDI provides the scientific equivalent

of one stop shopping where
we can use that one source

to get access to this
massive amount of big data

that then comes to us and
rapidly accelerates our ability

to analyze the movements of
our animals and understand why.

- I think when you understand
how OCEARCH started,

our actual mission becomes
really obvious, you know?

Returning our world's oceans
to balance and abundance.
And ultimately, a lot of that is policy.

OCEARCH has developed trusted
scale in the ocean space.
Policy makers reach out to us

for kind of an independent
centrist viewpoint on issues.
I mean, for me, it's very personal.

I got guys I love who've

for decades that literally put
their body parts on the line
so that these scientists can do something
that's amazing for our grandkids.
I am gonna make sure that mattered.
